title: üöÄ Deep Dive into Physical AI: NavDP and Diffusion Policies

content.raw:
üöÄ Deep Dive into Physical AI: NavDP, Diffusion Policies, and Custom Robots
I‚Äôve recently been diving deep into the world of Physical AI and Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models. 

My goal is simple: master the stack from the underlying research logic to the simulation environments to become a specialized engineer in the embodied AI space.

One project that recently caught my eye is NavDP (Navigation Diffusion Policy).

üß† The Technical Breakdown: How NavDP Actually Works NavDP isn't just a standard navigation stack; it is a unified framework designed for cross-embodiment navigation without needing real-robot training data. 
Based on the architecture, here is what makes it distinct:

Embodiment-Aware Planning: Unlike traditional policies that might overfit to a specific hardware, NavDP utilizes a data generation pipeline that distinguishes between "accessible" and "prohibited" areas based on the robot's physical dimensions (as seen in the generated cost maps).

The Diffusion-Critic Loop: The core magic happens in the Navigation Diffusion Policy. It uses a diffusion process to generate a distribution of potential trajectories.

Dual Supervision: The model is trained with both Action Supervision (to suggest paths) and Critic Supervision (to evaluate safety). This allows the system to generate a trajectory and then have the critic "filter" it, selecting the safest path that avoids obstacles while respecting the specific kinematics of the robot.

üõ†Ô∏è The Hands-on: Isaac Sim & The Lekiwi Swap To put this research to the test, I decided to go beyond the provided defaults. Instead of using the standard Dingo robot, I integrated the Lekiwi (a low-cost, 3-wheel holonomic base) into the NavDP framework within NVIDIA Isaac Sim.

The Challenge:
Asset Integration: Swapping a robot forced me to dive into URDFs, sensor placement (RGB-D alignment), and rigid body physics.

Proof of Generalization: This was the ultimate test of the paper's claims. By applying the NavDP policy to a completely different kinematic chain (Lekiwi's omni-wheels vs. Dingo), I could verify the robustness of the "Zero-Shot" transfer capabilities.

üéØ Final Thoughts & Credits Bridging the gap between reading a research paper and executing it in a simulator is where the real engineering growth happens.

A huge shoutout to the team at Intern Labs (Shanghai AI Laboratory) for their incredible work on open-sourcing this research. Their "Unified Navigation Data Generation Pipeline" is a massive step forward for Sim-to-Real applications. Also, this workflow wouldn't be possible without the robust simulation tools provided by NVIDIA Omniverse.

üîó Check out the code and the paper here: https://lnkd.in/dJQjcyqj

content.markdown:
# üöÄ Deep Dive into Physical AI: NavDP, Diffusion Policies, and Custom Robots

I‚Äôve recently been diving deep into the world of **Physical AI** and **Vision-Language-Action (VLA)** models. My goal is simple: master the stack from the underlying research logic to the simulation environments to become a specialized engineer in the embodied AI space.

## üß† The Technical Breakdown: How NavDP Actually Works

**NavDP (Navigation Diffusion Policy)** isn't just a standard navigation stack; it is a unified framework designed for cross-embodiment navigation without needing real-robot training data.

*   **Embodiment-Aware Planning**: Utilizes a data generation pipeline that distinguishes between "accessible" and "prohibited" areas based on the robot's physical dimensions.
*   **The Diffusion-Critic Loop**: Uses a diffusion process to generate a distribution of potential trajectories.
*   **Dual Supervision**: Trained with both Action Supervision (to suggest paths) and Critic Supervision (to evaluate safety).

## üõ†Ô∏è The Hands-on: Isaac Sim & The Lekiwi Swap

I integrated the **Lekiwi** (a low-cost, 3-wheel holonomic base) into the NavDP framework within **NVIDIA Isaac Sim**.

*   **Asset Integration**: Dived into URDFs, sensor placement (RGB-D alignment), and rigid body physics.
*   **Proof of Generalization**: Verified the robustness of the "Zero-Shot" transfer capabilities by applying the policy to a unique kinematic chain.

üéØ **Final Thoughts**: Bridging the gap between research and simulation is where the real engineering growth happens. Shoutout to the team at **Intern Labs** (Shanghai AI Laboratory) for their work on NavDP and **NVIDIA Omniverse** for the simulation tools.

üîó [Check out the code and paper here](https://lnkd.in/dJQjcyqj)
content.summary: Exploring cross-embodiment navigation with NavDP and Isaac Sim, from research logic to real-world robot integration.

title: ‚öôÔ∏èü§ñ Scaling Robot Training with AI-Generated 3D Worlds

content.raw:
‚öôÔ∏èü§ñ From days of scene building to minutes of world generation for robot training.


I have been exploring how AI generated 3d worlds can significantly improve robot training and data collection pipelines when paired with NVIDIA Omniverse Isaac Sim.

Using World Labs Marble AI a single world can be generated in 6 to 10 minutes and then reused to create massive environmental variation. Lighting, layout, clutter, and textures can all be randomized, making it extremely effective for domain generalization during training.

This approach was originally featured in an NVIDIA Developer Blog on Isaac Sim
 üëâ https://lnkd.in/denAvDF6

I expanded on this by testing Isaac Sim tasks inside AI generated environments, including adapting the orange picker scene to run inside Marble generated worlds. This already helps with domain randomization, but the real impact will be for movement and locomotion based tasks, where exposure to diverse geometry, scale, and layout is critical for robust policy learning.

One key limitation I observed:
 ‚Ä¢ Collision meshes are generally usable but low fidelity. Large appliances and major structures have reasonable colliders, while smaller details like flower pots or decor are inconsistent. This is fine for navigation and locomotion, but precision manipulation will still need refinement.

Even with this limitation, this is a huge step up from manually authored simulated worlds in engines like Unity or Unreal. Instead of spending days building environments, you can focus on scaling data diversity, which is what modern robot learning pipelines actually need.
content.markdown:
# ‚öôÔ∏èü§ñ From days of scene building to minutes of world generation for robot training

I have been exploring how AI-generated 3D worlds can significantly improve robot training and data collection pipelines when paired with **NVIDIA Omniverse Isaac Sim**.

### Scaling Diversity with Marble AI
Using **World Labs Marble AI**, a single world can be generated in 6 to 10 minutes and then reused to create massive environmental variation. Lighting, layout, clutter, and textures can all be randomized, making it extremely effective for **domain generalization**.

This approach was originally featured in an [NVIDIA Developer Blog](https://lnkd.in/denAvDF6).

### Testing in Generated Environments
I expanded on this by testing Isaac Sim tasks inside AI-generated environments, including adapting the orange picker scene. This helps with domain randomization, especially for locomotion-based tasks where diverse geometry is critical.

### Key Observations & Limitations
*   **Collision Meshes**: Generally usable but low fidelity. Fine for navigation, but precision manipulation still needs refinement.
*   **Efficiency**: A huge step up from manually authored worlds in Unity or Unreal. Instead of building environments, you can focus on scaling data diversity.
content.summary: How AI-generated environments in NVIDIA Isaac Sim are revolutionizing domain randomization and scale in robot learning pipelines.

title: üîä Audio Data Engineering for Production-Level AI

content.raw:
‚ú® Wrapping up my one month contractual full time role at My Shadow Life

I recently completed a one month contract at My Shadow Life, working closely with Ayush Rai, supervised by Boktiar Ahmed Bappy, and guided by the founder Jeremy Malai.

Even within a short period, the role gave me hands on exposure to production level AI and ML data engineering challenges at scale.
Although I cannot disclose the internal stack or proprietary methods due to NDA, my work focused on several high impact areas:

‚Ä¢ Audio Data Engineering transforming continuous, noisy real world audio streams into clean, structured, research ready datasets
 ‚Ä¢ AI and ML driven preprocessing applying advanced denoising, segmentation, and quality improvement techniques to extract meaningful signal from long form audio
 ‚Ä¢ Pipeline and workflow automation building reliable processing flows, automating multi stage transformations, and ensuring consistent output quality
 ‚Ä¢ Containerization and deployment packaging components through Docker for reproducible, scalable execution
 ‚Ä¢ Data readiness for downstream AI tasks preparing high quality datasets suited for speech, diarization, and other ML workloads
 ‚Ä¢ Knowledge graph generation contributing in the later weeks to structuring cleaned audio derived information into organized knowledge graph formats
This role strengthened my capability as an Audio Data and AI ML Engineer, especially in designing robust data pipelines, handling messy real world audio, and building automated workflows that support research teams and high quality ML tasks.

Grateful to the entire team for the trust and collaboration. Excited to take these skills into my next challenge.
content.markdown:
# ‚ú® Audio Data Engineering at My Shadow Life

I recently completed a one-month contract at **My Shadow Life**, focused on high-impact AI/ML data engineering challenges.

### Focus Areas:
*   ** Audio Data Prep**: Transforming noisy real-world audio into research-ready datasets.
*   **Preprocessing**: Advanced denoising and segmentation.
*   **Automation**: Building reliable processing flows and Docker containerization.
*   **Knowledge Graphs**: Structuring cleaned audio information into organized formats.

This role strengthened my capability in handling messy real-world audio and building automated workflows for ML tasks. Grateful for the collaboration! üéß
content.summary: Completion of a contract at My Shadow Life, focusing on denoising, segmentation, and knowledge graphs from audio streams.

title: ‚úàÔ∏è PLANE RUNNER: Research on Procedural & Adaptive Flight Games

content.raw:
PLANE RUNNER: A Procedural and Adaptive Framework for Endless Flight Games

As I continue deep-diving into AI/ML foundations, I‚Äôve been equally focused on applying those concepts inside interactive systems especially where AIML meets game development.

Super excited to share that our research paper has now been published in the International Journal of Research and Analytical Reviews (IJRAR)
published paper.

This project was built with Aadil Rayeen and under the guidance of Kunal Pandey where we explored how Procedural Content Generation (PCG) and Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment (ADA) can work together to create endlessly evolving environments similar to the ones shown in the screenshots below from our Unity MVP.

üîπ Procedural Terrain Generation using noise-based variation and modular tiles
 üîπ Adaptive Difficulty that responds to player performance in real time
 üîπ Mobile-optimized pipeline with object pooling, batching, and lightweight shaders
 üîπ Unity 2021.3 implementation demonstrating stable real-time generation and obstacle evolution

The paper highlights how PCG + adaptive models can push mobile games beyond static level design, aligning with modern trends in AI-driven generative systems and intelligent gameplay tuning.

This work sits right at the intersection of AI, simulation, and real-time systems areas I‚Äôm now actively upskilling in alongside vision-language-action models, Isaac Sim workflows, and robotics-focused AIML.
Excited for the next phase of learning and experimentation.

content.markdown:
# ‚úàÔ∏è PLANE RUNNER: A Procedural and Adaptive Framework for Flight Games

Super excited to share that our research paper has been published in the **International Journal of Research and Analytical Reviews (IJRAR)**.

This project explored how **Procedural Content Generation (PCG)** and **Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment (ADA)** can create endlessly evolving game environments.

### Key Features:
*   **Procedural Terrain**: Noise-based variation and modular tiles.
*   **Adaptive Difficulty**: Responds to player performance in real time.
*   **Mobile-Optimized**: Object pooling and lightweight shaders.

This work sits at the intersection of AI, simulation, and real-time systems‚Äîareas I‚Äôm actively upskilling in. üöÄ
content.summary: Our research on PCG and Adaptive Difficulty in flight games has been published in IJRAR.

title: üó£Ô∏è Building Agentic RAG Chatbots: A Consultancy Wrap-up

content.raw:
Wrapping up my consultancy engagement with CREO AI Pvt. Ltd., conducted officially under my college and the Department of AI & ML.

This was a paid project-based collaboration where our team worked on building a voice-based chatbot powered by Retrieval-Augmented Generation and Agentic AI, tailored to CREO AI‚Äôs internal requirements.

Across this engagement, I contributed to:
 ‚Ä¢ Designing and implementing end-to-end chatbot workflows
 ‚Ä¢ Integrating RAG pipelines with CREO AI‚Äôs internal API endpoints
 ‚Ä¢ Building core components of the agentic automation system
 ‚Ä¢ Ensuring seamless integration with provided tools
 ‚Ä¢ Testing, documentation, and performance optimization
 
Our team was formally recognized through an affiliation agreement, with full access to tools, APIs, and complete development ownership of the product.
 
This experience strengthened my foundations in Agentic AI, workflow automation, and applied RAG engineering, and gave me real exposure to building systems that balance technical depth with practical deployment needs.

Grateful to everyone who guided this journey 
Abhishek Bhate, (Founder)
Dr. Shiwani Gupta, ( HOD AI&ML)
and my teammate Ayush Rai for their constant support and direction throughout the project.

As I now transition into my winter internship and upcoming AIML work, I‚Äôm excited to build further on these learnings.

Onward to the next chapter. üöÄ

title: üèóÔ∏è Exploring Architecture at the Intersection of Agents & Blockchain

content.raw:
Two weeks into my Project Internship at Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), and it has already been one of the most unique experiences in my journey so far.
 
Our team doesn‚Äôt operate like a traditional SDE unit instead, we work at the exploratory and architectural layer where ideas begin. We evaluate new experimental concepts, take them through POT (Proof of Technology), and shape them into early MVP directions after validating feasibility.

I can only share the work at a very high level, but our project sits at a rare and exciting intersection of:

 üîπ Internal + External Public Agents
 üîπ Blockchain-aligned mechanisms
 üîπ Concepts around token movement 
 üîπ Security-focused HLV system design reviews
 üîπ Research on viability of emerging technologies

This role gives me room not just to build, but to think contributing to research, system architecture, and early-stage validation, deciding what can work, what cannot, and why.

Grateful to be working alongside Aadil Rayeen and Diya Manapetty, and guided by our mentor Nitaa Khare, whose direction has been instrumental in navigating this exploration-first environment.

Onwards. üöÄ

title: üì¶ Lean AI Infrastructure: Reducing Docker Bloat by 66%

content.raw:
üöÄ Building for Production, Not Just for Demo

Currently preparing a client‚Äôs multi-microservice AI system for production optimizing it from the ground up instead of fixing it later.

While setting up the architecture, we noticed how easily AI containers can bloat:
- Each service (8 total) used torch, transformers, etc.
- Even CPU-only services were built on GPU base images.
- The default pytorch/pytorch:2.1.0-cuda11.8-cudnn8-runtime image was ~12GB üòÖ

‚öôÔ∏è What we did:
- Switched to a minimal CUDA runtime base ‚Üí FROM nvidia/cuda:11.8.0-runtime-ubuntu20.04
- Installed PyTorch 2.1.0 manually via pip
- Dropped conda entirely (huge overhead)
- Built shared CPU & GPU base images so all services reuse layers
- Split upload & ingest modules for edge deployment, preprocessing close to data sources

üí° Result:
- Image size: 12GB ‚Üí 4GB
- Saved ~6 - 8GB per service
- Faster image pulls & deploys
- Lower runtime overhead and storage cost on GPU nodes
- Cleaner, production-ready Docker setup

Optimization isn‚Äôt only about faster models it‚Äôs also about smarter systems.

 The goal: lean, reproducible, and deployment-ready AI infrastructure from day one.

content.markdown:
# üöÄ Building for Production, Not Just for Demo

Optimized a client‚Äôs multi-microservice AI system from the ground up. We saw significant bloat in the initial setup (~12GB per service).

### ‚öôÔ∏è Optimization Steps:
*   Minimal CUDA runtime base.
*   Manual PyTorch installation (dropped Conda).
*   Shared CPU & GPU base images.
*   Split modules for edge deployment.

### üí° Result:
*   Image size: **12GB ‚Üí 4GB**.
*   Faster pulls, lower costs, and production-ready infrastructure. Optimization is about smarter systems! üì¶
content.summary: Optimizing production AI containers: from 12GB to 4GB images using minimal runtimes and shared layers.

title: üê≥ Snappy Docker Builds: 20m to 5m Optimization

content.raw:
üöÄ Streamlining Docker Builds: Small Tweaks, Big Wins

Recently spent some time tuning our multi-service Docker builds nothing broken, but definitely room to make things snappier.
Instead of chasing big rewrites, I focused on the small flags and caching tricks that often get overlooked:

üîß What Changed
- Enabled BuildKit caching so layers actually get reused
- Parallelized multi-base builds to cut total time
- Split heavy ML deps (PyTorch, TensorFlow) into shared base layers
- Added simple flags for single-service builds, GPU detection, and cache skips
- Auto-switched between CPU/GPU builds for better resource use

‚è±Ô∏è Results
- Build time down from ~20 mins ‚Üí 4‚Äì5 mins
- Rebuilds now almost fully cached
- Smaller images for non-ML services
- Less manual setup for devs

üí≠ Takeaway
 DevOps isn‚Äôt always about new tools it‚Äôs about knowing how things already work, and using the right flags wisely.
 Small, quiet optimizations that save real time and compute.

üòù (‚Ä¶and having 160GB RAM doesn‚Äôt hurt either)

title: üîÑ Reviving TradingViewPlus: A Story of OSS Contribution

content.raw:
Hacktoberfest 2025 Contributing Back to Open Source

This Hacktoberfest, I decided to give some long-overdue attention to a small but incredibly useful project I‚Äôve been using for over 3 years TradingviewPlus by Tiqur.

It‚Äôs a niche TradingView extension that improves the charting experience for a few hundred dedicated users. The project had been quiet for a while, with 30+ open issues piling up as TradingView‚Äôs codebase evolved. Over the past three weeks and 40+ hours , I‚Äôve focused on bringing it back to life:

 ‚úÖ Fixed 25+ issues, from broken UI components to major keybind refactors
 ‚úÖ Migrated build scripts from Bash to Node.js for better cross-platform support
 ‚úÖ Created 9 merged and 3 open PRs improving stability and functionality
Most of the codebase runs on TypeScript, with some automation and packaging handled through JS. The next beta release will roll out these fixes soon and it feels great to see the bugs that annoyed me for months finally gone.

Hacktoberfest is often seen as a time to chase big-name repos like Node.js or LangChain, but contributing doesn‚Äôt have to mean scaling mountains. Sometimes it‚Äôs about supporting the smaller tools that quietly improve your workflow every day.

If you use it contribute to it. That‚Äôs how open source truly moves forward.
(Also working on a LangChain issue next!)

https://lnkd.in/dC4Da_VH

# üöÄ Portfolio Pre-Release

Just pushed the pre-release of my portfolio site! Built the experience around high-quality binaries running at **60fps/1080p** with ~1s load times, backed by a CDN and aggressive caching.

### Visual Stack:
*   Parallax layers
*   Rotating backgrounds
*   Procedural noise for lively motion

Tech stack write-up is live on GitHub! Stay tuned for more effects and content next week. üíª
content.summary: Pre-release of my portfolio site featuring parallax layers and aggressive caching for ~1s load times.

title: üìê 99% Can‚Äôt Spot the Loop: Crafting Perfect Scenes

content.raw:
üîÅ 99% Can‚Äôt Spot the Loop ü§ô

Spent an unreasonable amount of time crafting perfectly looping scenes for my portfolio 10 unique environments, with day and night versions. Every frame tuned, every texture balanced. It's not Just Dark and Light Mode , it's the vibe of the Day

Used small but powerful tricks like ramping up particle speed toward the loop‚Äôs end to mask transitions. The goal: make something you could stare at forever without seeing the break.

These loops aren‚Äôt just tests they‚Äôre scenes I genuinely love. They‚Äôre built from the wallpapers and vistas I‚Äôve had on my screen for thousands of hours. Optimized, refined, and finally assembled into something that feels alive.

üé® Credits to the amazing artists and open assets on GitHub that made these worlds possible.

üëâ Watch the full video and try to spot where it loops.
Answer : 3 loops

title: üöÄ The 300x Speed Leap: 7 Years of Storage Evolution

content.raw:
‚öôÔ∏è From 2018 to 2025 ‚Äì The 300√ó Speed Leap üöÄ

HDD ‚Üí SATA ‚Üí NVMe Gen 4 ‚Üí NVMe Gen 5

Watching storage tech evolve this fast feels unreal.
Here‚Äôs my personal speed timeline over the years:

üóìÔ∏è 2018: HDD ‚Äì 200 MB/s (patience was a skill üòÖ)
üóìÔ∏è 2020: SATA SSD ‚Äì 550 MB/s (finally no more lag!)
üóìÔ∏è 2024: NVMe Gen 4 ‚Äì 7000 MB/s (gaming + dev became smooth)
üóìÔ∏è 2025: NVMe Gen 5 ‚Äì 14,000 MB/s (lightning-fast AI & LLM workloads)

That‚Äôs ~300√ó faster in just 7 years. What used to take minutes now loads before your coffee‚Äôs ready. ‚òï
content.markdown:
# ‚öôÔ∏è From 2018 to 2025: The 300√ó Speed Leap üöÄ

Watching storage tech evolve this fast feels unreal. Here‚Äôs my personal speed timeline over the years:

*   üóìÔ∏è **2018**: HDD ‚Äì 200 MB/s
*   üóìÔ∏è **2020**: SATA SSD ‚Äì 550 MB/s
*   üóìÔ∏è **2024**: NVMe Gen 4 ‚Äì 7000 MB/s
*   üóìÔ∏è **2025**: NVMe Gen 5 ‚Äì 14,000 MB/s

That‚Äôs ~300√ó faster in just 7 years. What used to take minutes now loads before your coffee‚Äôs ready! ‚òï
content.summary: Reflecting on the rapid evolution of storage tech from HDD to NVMe Gen 5 and its impact on dev/AI workloads.

I‚Äôm now open to work in the areas of AI Engineering, Cloud Consulting, and Applied AI, and excited to collaborate with professionals driving innovation in this space.

title: ü§ñ Engineering Around Roadblocks: An ESP32 Wake-on-LAN Bot

content.raw:
üí° One thing I‚Äôve learned as an engineer: problems often look bigger than they really are until you slice them down and solve them piece by piece.

Recently, I faced a simple but frustrating issue: my ISP wouldn‚Äôt allocate me a public IP. For most people, that‚Äôs a roadblock. For me, it became a weekend project.

Instead of relying on the ISP, I set up an ESP32-based Wake-on-LAN bot that connects with Telegram. Now, with a single /wol command, I can power on my PC remotely no static IP required.

It‚Äôs not a groundbreaking AI system (that‚Äôs where I spend most of my time), but it‚Äôs a neat reminder of what a little coding + hardware tinkering can achieve. Sometimes, solving problems isn‚Äôt about waiting for infrastructure to change it‚Äôs about engineering around it.

üîπ GitHub Repo: https://lnkd.in/d2AzDupC

üîπ Demo Video: https://lnkd.in/dhAQa2UV

Would love to hear what‚Äôs the smallest project you‚Äôve built that saved you from a big headache?

Faced a roadblock: my ISP wouldn‚Äôt allocate a public IP. Instead of waiting, I built an **ESP32-based Wake-on-LAN bot** connected to Telegram.

Now, a single `/wol` command powers on my PC remotely‚Äîno static IP required. It‚Äôs a neat reminder that solving problems is about engineering around infrastructure roadblocks. ü§ñ

[üîπ Check the GitHub Repo](https://lnkd.in/d2AzDupC)

title: üèÜ Secured 8th Rank at Intel National Gen AI Hackathon

content.raw:
üéâ¬†ùóßùóµùóøùó∂ùóπùóπùó≤ùó± ùòÅùóº ùó¶ùóµùóÆùóøùó≤ ùó¢ùòÇùóø ùó¶ùòÇùó∞ùó∞ùó≤ùòÄùòÄ ùóÆùòÅ ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùóúùóªùòÅùó≤ùóπ ùóûùó£ùó•ùóúùóòùóß ùó°ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùóÆùóπ ùóüùó≤ùòÉùó≤ùóπ ùóõùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùóÆùòÅùóµùóºùóªüèÜ


I‚Äôm excited to announce that my team, Tech Enerzal, secured the ùü¥ùòÅùóµ ùóøùóÆùóªùó∏ at the ùóúùóªùòÅùó≤ùóπ ùóûùó£ùó•ùóúùóòùóß ùó°ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùóÆùóπ ùóüùó≤ùòÉùó≤ùóπ ùóöùó≤ùóª ùóîùóú ùóõùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùóÆùòÅùóµùóºùóª held in ùóñùóºùó∂ùó∫ùóØùóÆùòÅùóºùóøùó≤ on 4th-5th October. Competing with over ùüØùü¨ùü¨+ ùòÅùó≤ùóÆùó∫ùòÄ and ùü≠ùü¨ùü¨ùü¨+ ùóΩùóÆùóøùòÅùó∂ùó∞ùó∂ùóΩùóÆùóªùòÅùòÄ from ùóÆùó∞ùóøùóºùòÄùòÄ ùóúùóªùó±ùó∂ùóÆ, this was an intense 24-hour challenge that tested the boundaries of our innovation and teamwork!

Our team, developed Enerzal, an AI-powered business assistant designed to tackle critical challenges in large organizations. ü§ñ
Enerzal addresses issues faced by HR and IT teams, which are often overwhelmed by repetitive queries related to HR policies, IT support, and event management.
Using an advanced NLP and Gen-based Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipeline, Enerzal automates these interactions, providing real-time responses to reduce wait times, enhance employee satisfaction, and relieve pressure on support teams. Fully customizable and secure, Enerzal seamlessly integrates with any system, whether deployed on local infrastructure or in the cloud‚Äîa solution with immense potential to scale and improve efficiency in diverse business environments. üåçüíº

To my amazing teammates, Ayush Rai and Aadil Rayeen ‚Äî thank you ‚ù§Ô∏è for your support, endless fun, and the incredible learning experience we shared. It was a joy working alongside you both, and I couldn‚Äôt have asked for better teammates! üôåüéâ

A huge thank you to our mentor, Mrs. Shilpa Mathur Ma'am üôè, for her invaluable guidance throughout the hackathon. We are also grateful to Dr. Shiwani Gupta Ma'am (HOD AIML) for her support and motivation üåü, and rajni bahuguna Ma'am (Activity Head) for her cooperation.

A special shoutout to the Intel Corporation and its executive Shriram Vasudevan (FIE, FIETE,SMIEEE) üéØ, for putting together such a well-coordinated event at KPRIET in partnership with Intel. His insights and feedback were instrumental in refining our solution, and his involvement alongside KPRIET ensured that the event ran smoothly from start to finish. ‚úÖüé§

We also want to extend our gratitude to the organizing team ‚Äî Ahamed Thaiyub A, Jeyasundar R, and Pranesh Rajeswaran ‚Äî whose flawless handling of the event made it an unforgettable experience. üôå And a big thanks to Rahamate alam ansari for taking care of all our accommodation needs and going above and beyond ensuring we were comfortable throughout the event. üõèÔ∏èü§ó.

This hackathon has been an incredible learning experience, both in terms of technical knowledge and personal growth.

content.markdown:
# üèÜ Intel National Gen AI Hackathon Success

Thrilled to announce that my team, **Tech Enerzal**, secured the **8th rank** at the Intel KPRIET National Level Gen AI Hackathon! üèÜ

Competing against 300+ teams, we developed **Enerzal**‚Äîan AI-powered business assistant using an advanced **NLP/RAG pipeline** to automate HR and IT queries. 

A huge thank you to my teammates and our mentors for the support! ü§ùü§ñ
content.summary: Team Tech Enerzal's success in building an AI-powered business assistant with RAG pipelines.
